comments.commentBody: If you truly believe that the Democratic part has been moving leftward during the Obama administration then you must have been living either on a different planet or in the Faux Noise bubble. This "leftward moving" Democratic administration has been pushing TPP, it has prosecuted more whistle blowers than the Bush administration before, it has done nothing about the Wall Street crooks who pushed us into the 2008 financial met-down, it has passed Obamcare which is right from Nixon's universal health care plan proposal (and which was 100% based on a Republican developed proposal), etc., etc. The Obama administration has been as corporatist as anyone can imagine, indeed far beyond.
Except of course most of what you allege it DID NOT HAPPEN....
Except of course that there was no violence, but do not let facts bother you.

I think Sanders makes a strong point, even if his chances of gaining the nomination are slim. The Democratic party has been moving leftward over the past eight years of the Obama administration. Hillary's incrementalism, her neoconservative tendencies on foreign policy, and her overtures toward Trump-skeptic Republicans are big reminders of the triangulation that her husband was well-known for. After the progressive gains of the past eight years, Democratic constituencies are not interested in triangulation, and a continuing challenge by Sanders ensures that the party stays true to its current direction.

In addition, Sanders has a point about the way the party has conducted its primaries, caucuses and debates. The DNC, under the direction of DWS, has been favoring Clinton from the get go. I won't engage in the conspiracy theories put forth by the more, er, passionate Sanders supporters, but the DNC's favoritism has been incredibly unseemly. The DNC should not tip the scales in such a way. If Sanders can wrest reform from the party by staying in the race, he will have done the integrity of the party a favor.
Did you forget that Bernie Sanders voted for the crime bill? Hillary Clinton did not. She was  not in Congress at that time!

I, too, wish Hillary had voted against the Iraq war. But let's bear in mind that the vote in the Senate was 77-23. Had she voted against, not a single thing would be different. It is also very convenient to forget the drum-cry for war that was roiling the nation. Even the NYT had to apologize for not fact-checking the propaganda or counter-balancing the hysteria.

The important question is this: Had there been a Democrat in the White House on 9/11 would we have undertaken the illegal war in Iraq? We all know the answer is NO.
You do realize that Bernie voted for the crime bill, right?

I think a lot of Clinton supporters don't take the differences between Sanders and Clinton supporters seriously. They think that the policy differences between the two candidates are exaggerated, that they're more style than substance. Since they see Sanders' campaign as pursuing a not particularly worthwhile cause, they obviously see it as a threat that Sanders may undermine Clinton's chances in the general election. They're also more likely to frame the issues in terms of headline politics: oh, someone threw a chair or the equivalent in Nevada, that must be what Sanders is all about.

But I think that it's a mistake to think that the fight within the Democratic party is an insignificant one. Since the 70s, the party has been so scared to tack to the left that it has ignored a large part of its base and has compromised a good deal of its essential values. Sanders presents a more egalitarian vision for the country than does Clinton, and it's important that our leftmost major party have an ideal like that to stand for.

Democratic party leaders have also been unaccountable for their past failures. Today Clinton says that she regrets voting for the authorization of the use of force in Iraq and for her support of the 1990s crime bill. Perhaps she is, and that's good. But we have elections, not to extract contrition, but so that there are consequences to bad decisions like those. Hopefully the next centrist Democrat thinks twice about making such decisions in the first place.

Granted that Sanders is a new member of the party. It is also known that Sanders joined the party for convenience. But, the party has the obligation to nominate the best and strongest candidate against Trump. Clinton is neither the best nor the strongest against Trump. The super delegates committed the crime of endorsing Clinton to discourage any primary fight. That is not democracy. All the super delegates must revert to neural position and make the decision at the convention providing reasons for their preference. If Democratic Party want to 'fix' the nomination, Sanders should seek presidency as an independent. He will have no problem raising billion dollar plus from his three million donors and he will win. Want to know about Trump and Clinton, just follow their cash.
And hillaria a crooked from Wall Street.

His anger is a reflection of the appalling treatment of the struggling working class who can't seem to catch a break, of the institutional obstacles that stand in the way of justice, of the churning out of corrupt forces that keep those with the best connections in power, of the moneyed interests who pander to their sharholders at the expense of our environment, and on and on....this is a giant of a man with a yuge heart...and his electrifying rallies are not the venues for spelling out details of his plans; go to his website and do a little digging.

I have lost all respect in Mr Sanders and the angry manner he has conducted himself. Instead off whining all the time-out the DNC, he should face the fact that he is not even a Democrat. Also, he has to start putting details on many of his proposals because he loses credibility every time he is pressed on the subject and his rhetorical responses come up empty.

My bottom-line is I have no intention of voting for an angry, 74 year old guy to be president of the USA.

Another article in the Times mentions that the next president may have to fill more than one Supreme Court vacancy.  If Bernie really cared about the direction this country is headed, he would not undermine the only candidate who will nominate candidates whose decisions will shape this country for decades to come.  The longer he's in the race, the better it is for Trump.
Hillaria a corrupt puppet from Wall Street. She even love war criminal Henry Kissinger,
Repeating outdated and unsubstantiated  Republican attacks does very little to change the fact that she is the odds on favorite to become the next POTUS. Then what will you do?
That baffles me when he says the Democrat party needs to welcome people in, they do, anyone can register as a Democrat, there is no litmus test.

Bernie is advocating for the party to be opened to all, forgetting that the reason he's even done so well is precisely because the party was wide open, allowing him to convert to Democrat at 11th hour so that he could take advantage of its infrastructure and primary process to launch his candidacy - advantages he would not have had as an independent candidate. Moreover, the party's nominating rules were already in place before he decided to run, so that none should have surprised him. After initially railing against superdelegates as "undemocratic", he and his supporters are now talking about flipping them to win the nomination even if he still trails in pledged delegates and total votes. In short, Bernie and his supporters are ready to use undemocratic means if that is what it would take to win him the nomination, while they continue railing against a system they see as "rigged" and undemocratic!

Bernie the sheep has completely disrobed and the wolf that was lurking underneath is now fully exposed for all to see. His transformation from a candidate who'd once defended Hillary against email-server-gate to one "willing to harm her in the homestretch" is nothing short of extraordinary. No bona fide Democrat should take a chance with a candidate who is clearly willing to literally crash the Dem Party because he's come up short.

America has never elected a candidate from the extremes of the political divide. Hillary is where most voters are and is thus our best choice!

"Both parties are publicly funded, and occupy a special place in our two party system. "

No, that is not correct. Federal matching funds are available for presidential campaigns, but are not for congressional races. Since 2000, most presidential candidates have refused federal matching funds, not wanting to be constrained by the eligibility conditions. In 2008 and 2012, Barack Obama refused government funds; in 2012, so did Mitt Romney.

In 2016, only Buddy Roemer of the Reform Party and Jill Stein of the Green Party have accepted federal matching funds so far. Even Sanders has turned down the public funding.

A few states have their own campaign subsidies for state and local offices.

No direct public funding is provided to the parties by the federal government, and I am not aware of any other indirect public funding.

Are you maybe counting the cost of mounting elections? Unfortunately, elections are supported because the Constitution requires it. And note that you don't have to belong to a political party in order to run for election. The Democrats receive no extra benefits from the federal government than the Green or Reform parties, and do not occupy a "special place in our two party system" in the context of federal funding.

Why shouldn't his delegates be disqualified for not showing up to vote or not being registered? If his campaign can't even manage to make sure their delegates fulfill the most basic requirements for participation, they really have no reason to complain, much less claim that their is some kind of conspiracy against them. They shouldn't blame others for their incompetence, and certainly not threaten others because they are frustrated at what are actually their own failures.

Re: Nevada, you have misunderstood me. Yes, I agree that the delegates screwed up by not registering or showing up, and rules are rules and currently state that this disqualifies them; fair enough. My point is not about the Sanders or the Clinton campaigns; I'm not taking sides there or saying that anything was rigged or unfair.

My point is about the delegate system and rules I think need to be re-thought for the future: I'm saying that currently the system is such that, if person A--one single person--screws up, that results in the votes of thousands and thousands of voters being thrown out, and that's a problem. If that is happening, the voters' voices are at risk of not being heard because of the screw-up of single individuals. We need to have a system where votes translate more directly into electoral results. I'm not claiming anything was rigged or unfair, just that we have a problem that needs to be fixed, for the future.

I certainly cannot condone thrown chairs, death threats, etc. But I am disturbed by the fact that, so far, I've seen no coverage of WHY Bernie's delegates were disqualified in such numbers. That is a striking state of affairs, and one that needs to be reported-on--whether or not it's evidence of a conspiracy.

Since the Times neglected to cover this, I went in search and found out that the delegates were disqualified for things like not showing up to vote, not having registered, etc. If these folks were contestants soley on their own behalf, one could understand disqualifying them. However, if this is how things are done, this means that the actions or non-actions of single individuals can have a direct bearing on who gets nominated for President. Clearly, there is a problem here, and it needs to be fixed.

The comments from women supporters of Mrs. Clintoin have been just as vehement and rude at times—directed at any man who disagrees with something about her policies or campaign, immediately calling him sexist or having fallen for the Right-wing smear campaign, or a Berniebro or -bot.

Unfortunately, there's enough nastiness on both sides to go around. When the campaign for the nomination os over, I hope everyone is able to figure out—and quickly—how best to defeat Mr. Trump, assuming he's the GOP nominee.

So interesting how you would like to categorize Sanders win in Oregon as a "landslide" because the spread was 56-44.  That same percentage spread represents Hillary's popular total primary votes over Sanders in all states. Wow.  She has been beating him overall in a landslide which wasn't the case for her against Obama in 2008.  So in my (non-magical thinking) world, a reasonable challenger would first tone it down, organize his campaign around taking the high road and choosing a few agenda items he'd like to push; and when he sees (after Indiana primary when Trump became the sole nominee of the other party) that there's absolutely no path to the nomination, he drops out and works to saving our democracy from the incredibly destructive forces lining up to support Trump.

I would like someone to explain what Clinton would do differently if Sanders were now out of the race. I grant some campaign mechanics would change. But to what imaginary "center" would she pivot, where the largest blocks of voters she must win over are Sanders' younger voters and the independent working class white voters over which Sanders is already battling Trump. What are the "radical" positions to which Sanders has pushed her that she might advantageously soft pedal or repudiate? It's not as if she is any longer spending much money or effort addressing Sanders' most barbed criticisms of her campaign financing. She's certainly no longer prepping to debate him. She effectively has the nomination locked up. So who is this more competitive Hillary whose emergence is being mysteriously held back by Bernie?

I can think of no more compelling case Clinton could make for her own candidacy to her own supporters and to Sanders' than going, no holds barred, at Trump right now, indeed, yesterday. The core discomfort with Clinton has always been that she and her campaign exude an air of "entitlement" and a dangerous penchant to sit on a lead and "triangulate" rather than actually leading. Nothing would better dispel that than a show of justified confidence in her nomination and a bit of fight. This constant whining out of her camp about Sanders and his supporters not giving up a lost cause just looks petty and weak. Not the impression one wants to make facing Trump.

Obama did not "handily" beat Clinton. In fact, she won the popular vote in the primary and lost the pledged delegate count by 100, far less than Sanders' deficit. But otherwise complete agreement that, however painful to his burgeoning ego, Sanders needs to accept the fact that the voters have chosen Clinton and not him.

A commenter suggested support for Sec. Clinton indicated a resignation to accept the status quo and was reflective, perhaps, of age. I’ll concede my age. I remember the violence surrounding the 1968 Democratic convention in Chicago. I remember Mayor Daley. I vividly remember Gore vs. Bush. I voted for Ralph Nader, who was not a spoiler. Despite his bona fide credentials, he was not ‘allowed’ to participate in the televised national debates. When it came down to tallying the votes, in my opinion, Mr. Gore acquiesced – he simply didn’t have the fire in the belly necessary to claim the presidency. I’ll never get over that. I don’t think the U.S. will ever get over the fallout from the resultant presidency as a result of that.

I’m a left wing bleeding heart liberal. Sec. Clinton is not nearly liberal enough for me. But I will vote for her. I think she’s a decent person who occasionally got some stuff wrong. (Join the club.) The status quo I hope she will maintain will be the continuance of societal advances fought for over the past decades including reproductive rights, gender rights, affordable healthcare, family rights, labor rights.

I don’t know what Mr. Trump is up to. I can’t tell if he’s pulling the Republicans to the left or pretending to do so long enough to snag ambivalent Democrats and then revert back to right-wing-land right after the election. The way some in his party are warming up to him, I’d say beware the Trojan horse, liberal friends.

@David,

Thank you for providing two of the points on which the repugnant Republicans would attack Sanders during a general election.

It's easy for Sanders and his supporters to point out that Sanders has an advantage in polls taken now in a Sanders versus Trump general election. Those numbers would change drastically once the Republicans began to attack Sanders's history.

Because of Sanders history as an unrepentant socialist, he is the candidate that would be easiest for Trump to defeat because Americans are deeply suspicious of socialism.

It calls to mind 1972 when Edmund Muskie would have been the more formidable opponent of Richard Nixon. The Nixon campaign succeeded in sidelining Muskie and getting George McGovern. McGovern won only two states and Nixon was re-elected.

This year is too important, with a Supreme Court vacancy not being filled because of the obstreperous Republican Senate, to have a longtime socialist as the nominee of the Democratic Party.
So democratic will keep pondering corrupt Wall Street. No way we e vote for a Wall Street toy.go Bernie for November election.

And yet Hillary being purchased for huge sums, with no massive audiences turning out to hear her speak, is the better candidate because she wins primaries that look nothing like general elections? Do people have any idea how crazy that sounds?
Hillary Clinton is not a progressive. When people say she is progressive it just shows an embarrassing level of ignorance.

Raising hundreds of millions of dollars and speaking before huge crowds of fervent young believers has gone to Bernie's head. Finally, he is getting the attention he has been craving during his decades-long activist and political career.  In the process of achieving his "revolution", he is willing to destroy the Democratic Party and risk electing Donald Trump to the Presidency. Gone are the days when he acknowledged that Clinton was just as much a progressive as he was. Now, in his effort to take over the Democratic Party, he and his staff and supporters have adopted the long-rehearsed Republican talking points about Hillary Clinton, along with accusing her of selling out to the big banks. He has no chance of being the Democratic nominee or being elected President. If he were to be elected somehow, he has no concrete plans for accomplishing his goals, other than having a "revolution" and calling his supporters to the streets. He and Trump are distorted mirror images of each other, both wanting to retreat from the world; both with extreme America First views; both appealing to mainly-white, alienated, politically naive constituencies; and both with a core of fanatical supporters who are willing to engage in verbal and physical violence. The Democratic Party should not cave in to Sanders's extortion. He has taken advantage of the Party and there is no excuse, other than sour grapes, for him to complain about Party rules this late in the game.
"Why don't they just start a party."? Then you'll accuse them of "pulling a Nader"!
Unfortunately, the DNC doesn't want to expand its base if that means undermining its neoliberal ("centrist") ideology.
MVH1, the same argument would apply if you were talking about the Bolshevik party. Democracy is more than a party machine.

Sadly, I have grown to detest this man. I've always thought he had his heart in the right place, but the last two months of Bernie have been like fingernails on the chalkboard.

He is acting incredibly irresponsibly, endangering the future of the republic with his Quixotic Quest. The fact is, Secretary Clinton has more pledged delegates. The only way Senator Sanders can win is by persuading the bulk of superdelegates to come to his side, and thereby nullify the popular vote for Secretary Clinton. Some populist, this Bernie.

If that happens, do not blame Bernie Sanders. Blame the real culprit: Hillary Clinton and the unscrupulous, overbearing, cheating and obscure political machine that supports her. If current polls indicates Bernie Sanders will defeat Trump, but it will be more difficult for Hillary Clinton to do the same, are you blaming Bernie Sanders for that?  If Sanders were out of the picture, do you think that will improve Mrs. Clinton's popularity/electability? I seriously doubt it. Without Sanders as a choice, many people will either not vote or vote for Trump. At the very  least, it will be a very, very close election and I do not see, in that case, the Republicans losing any seats in the House.

the nader vote got us eight years of Bush.  those same voters' opposite, disaffected and disoriented fringe voters are now this country's best chance to get a Democrat in the white house.  fatheads who choose idealism over pragmatism will enjoy something like the pleasure of Afghanistan/Iraq and a great recession for the next eight years. I can't stand idiots on either side of our political divide, who apparently number in the gazillions.
Beautifully said. The entitlement of the clinton supporters and dnc establishment is nauseating.

@jok

Gore voters got us eight years of Bush. If they all voted Nader, Nader would have been President. We would have avoided the Iraq War, since Nader made non-intervention part of his platform.

Are you outraged by my statement? But why? Nader has as much right to run for President as Gore, and his supporters had as much a right to vote for him as Gore supporters had to vote for their guy. Politics is the art of compromise, and compromise cannot be a one-way street.

If you still do not see the point I am making, I can only say you have a confused view of how electoral politics work.

Instead of being outraged at Sanders (as they were at Nader,) Democrats should see these insurgent liberal candidates as warning signs that the party is neglecting a segment of its voters. After all, why is it incumbent on Sanders or Nader to send their voters to the Democratic centrist candidate? Stamping one's feet about it makes no sense. As one Nader supporter once pointed out, he isn't a Democratic voter, he is a Green Party voter. He didn't owe Al Gore his vote. His vote needed to be earned.

I think the Democratic Party has grown complacent during the Obama years. I hope Clinton and the Democratic leadership don't make the mistake of pandering to the center while taking Sanders voters for granted come time for the general election.

Just one problem with that argument. Hillary Clinton has won the votes of the majority of democrats. Independents, who are not democrats by choice, were more likely to vote for Bernie.
Bernie's temperament has always been an issue for me, even though I liked his stand on the issues. Now that his actions & lack of action (not condemning the violence & death threats in Nevada) are being brought to the voters' attention he may lose some of those independent voters.

Stephen
Bernie is not destroying the system. He is making it fairer and more just. It does not matter if he loses to Hillary. The system must be changed.

And thereby insures that we get to live under a President Trump.  It might be wise to dismount from the high horse of moral superiority and to look at who is better able to manage the US Government for the benefit of the many rather than the very, very few.  Looking at the resumes of each, Hillary seems far better qualified.

And replaces it with what?
Bernie has never filled in the blanks on how he is going to reach his repeatedly stated goals.

Bernie is not so much about defeating Hillary in the Democratic primaries (Hillary's coronation has always been a foregone conclusion) but about shattering the establishment stronghold on the Democratic Party and more generally that of the Democrat-Republican duopoly. The two party system, probably inevitable under our deeply flawed constitution, needs to be reconfigured at the very least, on both sides, so as to be more reflective of actual political sentiment and responsive to the national problems. That is why it is so important that Bernie play this all the way through. He seems to understand this. He is in no way obligated to the Democratic elites to step aside to clear the way for Hillary. That they think they have a right to ask him that shows how little they understand what this electoral cycle is about. Bernie cannot win the nomination unless he destroys that establishment.

The debate schedule thing was about all of the debates being on Saturday nights during big football games.
Just because some wacko (who could just as easily be a Clinton supporter trying to make Sanders look bad) makes a death threat doesn't mean its Sander's fault. They denounced the cursing, the chair trowing, and the death threats (unlike Trump who never denounced any of the violence of his supporters) and they also denounced what they contend was the breaking of the rules which they contend contributed to the violence.
Considering the vice chair of the DNC resigned to protest how unfairly the party was fixing the race against Sanders, I find their allegations believable, and I would like to see some actual investigation, instead of just trying to blame Sanders for the acts of people he can't control.

Bernie Sanders now appears to have a "god" complex. All those crowds assembling to see him appear to be spectacle seeking voyeurs. Must be hard for a politician who has held public office for so long and accomplished so little to realize that he is going nowhere. I hope reality hits soon before Democrats lose the White House because of his ego.

I don't think so. I think the media is trying to reduce Bernie Sanders to such small definitions when he is in fact, executing his sense of responsibility to all of the people who have supported him to bring his platform to the convention and to fight for it. Trivializing his candidacy is yet another nail in the coffin of this Experiment In Democracy.

Really? All I hear from Hillary is "I" and all I hear from Sanders is "we".

We all know Sanders' campaign platform - battling income inequality, taking on large corporations...

What's Hillary's?
Sanders's egotism has overcome his idealism.
Bravo!

Deli counters and delis are mostly gone, except as high priced, trendy places. Like you, lox was a luxury in my childhood, a little bit smeared all over a bagel and cream cheese for flavor, usually as the occasional weekend treat. Of course, back then, bagels were bagels, boiled, baked, and 15 cents, not small, circular loaves of textureless bread costing a buck or more nor frozen dough rings.

Of course much the same can be said about pizza.
And you can get it still. Not as common, but available from the few North End fishmongers still in business. Now if only we had better access to fresh fish!

I grew up in North Winnipeg, neighborhood majority Jewish, in the 1950's, most of my schoolmates were 2nd generation Canadian with grandparents from Eastern Europe. The delis carried real lox. Not the soft brine-soaked stuff we get now; refrigerate that and even then it's good for but a week or so after it's opened. But the real thing, fully cured. I think it was smoked. Out on the deli counter unrefrigerated, a solid slab, stayed edible for about forever. The proprietor used a huge razor-sharp knife, almost a thin-bladed machete really, to cut thin slices to order. When we were feeling flush, I'd be sent to the deli, buy maybe 2 slices, it would last four of us for two days of lunches. I remember yet coming home from grade school for a lunch of a bagel, cream cheese, and shreds of the lox, flavoring only; we were too poor to cover the cheese with a solid piece.

Maybe I'll have to start making my own.
Would that the pendulum swings not too far, but alas, that is unlikely. It can still be done, but the window is small, and so are the minds confronted with change.

Keep fantasising, Prof!

I suspect that you do not live in the "EU" and do not have a lot of evidence to go on.

The "EU" is destroying the countries within ist borders in a multitude of ways:

The Eurozone is destroying the economies especially of those countries which are at its edge.. Countries in the same Position but outside the Eurozone are better off.

The Schengenzone has long made it too easy for parasites and even worse criminals to move about. It is part of the cause of the refugee crisis which, among other things is resulting in the reintroduction into Europe of diseases that had dies out there and the spread of other diseases.

The people who control the "EU" will not listen to the people and have pratically shown contempt for democracy, which must make some people see violence as the only way to solve problems.

Here in Germany, the Frankfurter Yllgemeine Reports massive left-wing violence agains AfD members and that thhe Establishment do not seem interested. Some AfD members believe that members of other parties enciurage this violence. They might well respond with similar violence. I hope not.

The poor state of economies has had a knock-on effectr on defence, which must encourage Putin etc

The far right ascendancy across the Western world reflects the  popular disenchantment with the existing ruling dispensations born out of the governance deficit and security concerns. Once the same is repeated under the emerging pseudo-nationalist demagogue dispensations with an added cost of social disharmony and distrust, it wouldn't take long for the voters to switch to the familiar liberal order, come next elections. In short, the current trend of the rightist revival born out of engendered anxieties and fear seems nothing more than a momentary desire for change.
